block.p: Lobbying Efforts Pick Up On Communications Issues As Congress nears adjournment, some of the most powerful corporations have enlisted lawmakers to add provisions into spending bills that could reshape the balance of power among phone companies, Internet companies, broadcasters and cable operators.

The measures would relax restrictions that have made it impossible for AT&T to expand further in the cable industry. They would save the regional Bell companies billions paid to local carriers that some rivals and groups say would be shifted to Internet users. And they would kill a plan to create hundreds of new low-power FM stations for churches, schools and community groups. [Page A1.]

Lobbying Efforts Pick Up On Communications Issues As Congress nears adjournment, some of the most powerful corporations have enlisted lawmakers to add provisions into spending bills that could reshape the balance of power among phone companies, Internet companies, broadcasters and cable operators.

The measures would relax restrictions that have made it impossible for AT&T to expand further in the cable industry. They would save the regional Bell companies billions paid to local carriers that some rivals and groups say would be shifted to Internet users. And they would kill a plan to create hundreds of new low-power FM stations for churches, schools and community groups. [Page A1.]

Earnings at 3M Beat Forecasts Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing said that its third-quarter profit rose 8 percent on increased sales of telecommunications and computer equipment in Asia. The results beat analysts' estimates by a penny. Shares rose $2.56, to $89.81, after the company said profits in the fourth quarter and next year would meet estimates. [C6.]

The Rise of an Internet Analyst Holly Becker, a Lehman Brothers analyst, has quickly become one of Wall Street's most influential voices on Internet stocks. But a closer look at Ms. Becker's record reveals that she has been wrong more than right this year. Ms. Becker notes that her recent ratings have been more negative, and more accurate, than her earlier comments. Market Place. [C16.]

Dow Edges Up in Sluggish Trading Blue-chip stocks moved higher, but some technology issues lagged behind in one of Wall Street's quietest sessions in recent weeks. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 45.13 points, or 0.44 percent, at 10,271.72. Some broader gauges were lower. The Nasdaq composite index was off 14.45 points, or 0.41 percent, at 3,468.69. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.15 points, to 1,395.78. [C17.]

Ex-Coke Executive Becomes Adviser Don Keough, who was president and chief operating officer of Coca-Cola for 12 years, is rejoining the company as an adviser to Coke's board and to Douglas Daft, its chairman and chief executive. [C14.]

J. Walter Thompson to Buy Tonic 360 In another shift in the realm of interactive advertising, J. Walter Thompson in New York is poised to acquire Tonic 360 of San Francisco, which specializes in digital branding campaigns. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

New Tool From Lotus Notes Creator Three years after leaving I.B.M., Ray Ozzie, the designer of the Lotus Notes program, will introduce his latest effort: a software tool intended to provide a wide range of new ways for workers to collaborate over the Internet. It is, in essence, a sort of Napster for the workplace. Mr. Ozzie is credited with pioneering the groupware category of software, including Notes, that permits teams of workers to share data and communicate. [C8.]

Confusing End to Auction in Italy After only three days of bidding, an auction for licenses to operate a new generation of wireless devices in Italy ended in confusion after a consortium backed by British Telecommunications backed out, leaving only five bidders for the five licenses. The government considered nullifying the auction but instead accepted the outcome, which raised about $10 billion, half as much as had been expected. [C14.]

G.M. to Make Small Car in China General Motors said that it would begin producing a small car in China in December, the first of several such offerings planned by some of the world's largest automakers, each hoping to dominate this country's potentially huge market. [World Business, Section W.]
U.S. Accused in Shrimp Trade Case Malaysia accused the United States of failing to revamp its laws to allow unrestricted shrimp imports. [World Business, Section W.]
